passages.text: 2025 results missed on one- offs, maintain Buy and raise TP reflecting strong volume trend and OPEX efficiency
002074.SZ 12m Price Target: Rmb45.40 Price: Rmb40.12 Upside: 13.2%

2Q25 missed on impairment loss. Gotion released its 2Q25 results after market on 29th Aug. 1) net profit of Rmb266mn, \(+32\%\) yoy, or \(+164\%\) qoq, below GSe by \(31\%\) (or \(\sim\) Rmb120mn); 2) gross profit of Rmb1.5bn, \(- 7\%\) yoy, or \(- 8\%\) qoq, below GSe by \(3\%\) ; 3) revenue of Rmb10.3bn, \(+11\%\) yoy, or \(+14\%\) qoq, above GSe by \(17\%\) ; 4) sales volume of \(\sim 22\) GWh, \(+47\%\) yoy, or \(+22\%\) qoq, beat GSe by \(25\%\) . We attribute Gotion's 2Q25 earnings miss to unexpected asset impairment of Rmb154mn which is associated with lithium price correction.

Unit GP headwinds in 2Q25 likely to relief. We estimate Gotion's 2Q25 battery unit GP \(\sim\) Rmb62/kWh, below GSe of \(\sim\) Rmb78/kWh and 1Q25 of Rmb84/kWh, due to 1) stronger than expected US tariff impacts this April which hindered export to US customers, 2) industry wide battery unit GP decline trend due to price competition, as showcased by peer company EVE Energy (Exhibit 1) and 3) unit DD&A inflation due to new capacity ramp up in 1H25 (Exhibit 2). We continue to expect unit GP recovery in the following quarters supported by suspension of US reciprocal tariff from May, market re- balance of battery SD and volume growth that dilute unit DD&A. (see China battery export tracker and China battery 2025 outlook)

OPEX efficiency backed by volume growth. Despite unit GP headwinds, we observed Gotion released better than expected OPEX efficiency in 2Q25 with OPEX registered at \(11\%\) of revenue, significantly below our earlier estimation of \(15\%\) . Considering a consistent OPEX ratio decline from \(14\% /12\% /11\%\) in 4Q24/1Q25/2Q25, we view our earlier OPEX ratio assumption of \(13\%\) for 2025E was overly estimated. We view Gotion's OPEX improvement backed by stronger than expected volume growth should sustain into the coming years. Accordingly, we move on to

lower Gotion's 2025- 27E OPEX assumptions to \(11\%\) from earlier \(13\%\) per year. We estimate, every 1pct OPEX rate decline leads to \(29\% /14\% /13\%\) net profit expansion in 2025- 2027E.

We raise 2026- 27E earnings by \(45\%\) and \(16\%\) , respectively, mainly supported by OPEX savings of Rmb444mn and Rmb1,081mn, based on lowered OPEX ratio assumptions, as well as \(13\%\) and \(1\%\) higher volume assumptions. Our 2025E earnings remain broadly unchanged, as we estimate lowered unit GP and impairment losses are nearly offset by \(12\%\) volume increase and \(\sim\) Rmb549mn OPEX savings (2.4pp of revised 2025E revenue).

We raise TP and maintain Buy rating: Our 12- m TP of Rmb45.4 (from Rmb28.8) is derived from an average of a near- and long- term valuation. We mark- to- market using a 3M average P/E of 27.4x (from 24.8x) for 2025- 26E average (from 2025E) to arrive at a near- term valuation, while employing a 15.0x long- term P/E for 2030E, discounted back to 2026E (from 2025E) at a \(10.8\%\) COE to derive a long- term valuation.
1. Slower-than-expected volume growth: We estimate every 1pct volume miss compared to our assumptions leads to \(4\% /2\% /3\%\) earnings downside in 2025E-2027E.
2. Share loss with major OEMs: Any share loss would undermine our revenue and earnings forecasts.

3. Stronger-than-expected price competition in the domestic market: If price competition exceeds our expectations, a Rmb10/kWh gross profit decline would lower earnings in 2025-26E by \(c.60\% /c.30\%\) , respectively.

Government subsidies (equivalent to 1- 3x of Gotion's 2022- 2024 net profit, reflects in 'other income') had been a major swing factor to Gotion's earnings. We update our subsidies forecasts (Exhibit 3) to reflect CAPEX based subsidies from China and production based subsidies from the US, expecting total subsidies to peak out in 2026E alongside Gotion's CAPEX peak before gradually fading out in the LT. We mainly 1. raised China CAPEX related subsidies to Rmb896mn / Rmb1,017mn in 2025E- 26E from earlier

Rmb655mn / Rmb595mn to factor in 1H25 results; 2. removed US production subsidies in 2026E- 2027E of Rmb256mn per year due to geopolitical uncertainties following the issuance of the One big beautiful bill act (OBBBA). Consequently, we estimate total subsidies to represent 58%/25%/7% of 2025- 2027E net profit, from earlier 42%/31%/24%, respectively.

Key downside risks: 1) Slower- than- expected overseas project progress; 2) share loss with major OEMs; and 3) stronger- than- expected price competition in the domestic market.

Gotion is a battery pioneer in China with a lithium iron phosphate (LFP) focus, ranked 4th by installation in 2024A. We are positive on the company's overseas investments, expecting it to benefit from a favorable cost- plus mechanism and support from potential financial subsidies, especially in the US. In addition, we view its cooperation with Volkswagen as an opportunity for it to upgrade its product mix and transition to the higher- end market. We are Buy- rated on the stock as we appreciate Gotion's potential as an early mover to transition from the price competitive domestic market to the lucrative overseas market, and expect further progress in overseas expansion to drive the stock. We view the stock as undervalued given the market has yet to factor in potential overseas investment return.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.

Not Rated (NR). Early- Stage Biotech (ES). An investment rating and a target price are not assigned pursuant to Goldman Sachs policy when this company neither has a drug, treatment or medical device that has passed a Phase II clinical trial nor a license to distribute a post- Phase II drug, treatment or medical device. Rating Suspended (RS).
